Answer Relavancy Reason: The landlord has a legal obligation to ensure that the carbon monoxide alarm is in working order.  Under the Smoke and Carbon Monoxide Alarm Regulations 2015 (as amended), landlords are required to install and maintain a working carbon monoxide alarm in any rented property with a solid fuel heating appliance, such as a fireplace, wood-burning stove, or gas boiler. The landlord is also responsible for replacing any faulty alarm.  As the landlord has failed to repair or replace the malfunctioning alarm after three weeks, the tenant can take the following actions: 1.  Send the landlord a formal written notice detailing the problem and requesting that they take action to rectify the situation. This notice should be sent via recorded delivery, so the tenant has proof of delivery. 2.  If the landlord fails to take action within a reasonable timeframe, the tenant can report the issue to the local council.  The council has the power to issue a notice to the landlord requiring them to comply with the regulations. 3.  If the landlord continues to fail to comply, the council can take legal action against them, which could include a fine.  In addition to these actions, the tenant may also be able to claim compensation from the landlord for any losses incurred as a result of the faulty alarm, such as any costs of staying in alternative accommodation or any medical expenses incurred.  The tenant should consult with a solicitor to discuss their options and to determine the best course of action in their specific circumstances.
